one.title: _The Strange Countess_                _Chapter One_
one.body: Bathroom's empty,
It is from my countess--I start on Monday.
Well, you can't say that I haven't looked after you,
You've been a darling,
Great!
You'll have to have that electrocuted, or whatever the word is,
Anyway, the countess will like your classy talk,
I don't believe I talk classily!
I'll bet that's what got _him_,
He's not common, like some of these pickers-up,
These eggs are burnt,
And a gentleman,
Mine is brass,
remarked the stenographer calmly,
This tea tastes like logwood,
Did you hear old Mackenzie last night?
He plays beautifully,
The middle of the night's no time to play anything,
It is a nice kind of craziness,
There's a time for everything,
It's your turn to take it down to him,
Thank you, thank you very much, Miss Reddle,
No, I'm sorry I didn't hear you,
Music is a grand profession,
He nodded emphatically and went on:
Women are funny creatures, Mr. Mackenzie,
Aye, they are,
Well, did he warn you off the boards?
You shouldn't tease the poor old man,
He ought to have more sense,

2.title: _The Strange Countess_                _Chapter Two_
2.body: About that scar on your arm,
I think Mr. Dorling had it----
You're going to Telsbury, by the so-called car?
Nothing jumps around inside me except my heart,
You have no right to run into me because you disapprove of my scarf,
You have been following me for months,
Offensive is the word you're wanting,
I want you to believe, Miss Reddle!

Will you start my car, please?
If you follow me now you'll have a shock,

3.title: _The Strange Countess_               _Chapter Three_
3.body: Getting tired of coming here, miss?
Prisons make me very tired and very sick at heart,
I've come to see Mrs. Desmond,
She'll be in her cell now,

You give my intelligence too great credit,
I thought you'd like to see them.

I can't believe it! It is incredible--impossible!
If they thought she was a murderess, why didn't they----
Ha--h'm--well, there was a reason, a very excellent reason.
She didn't know, perhaps doesn't know now,
Do--do you remember the name by which the baby was christened?

4.title: _The Strange Countess_                _Chapter Four_
4.body: Whatever is the matter with you, girl?

You sit down there while I give you a slight sedative,
I think I'm a little mad,

179 Bedford Row, I think it is?

Do you know the prison? Have you been inside, I mean?
Yes, I've been inside once or twice,
Don't bother about my car; it is here,

Ah!

My dear, I can't tell you now, not--not in this mood,
She walked to the French windows and opened them.

She stepped out on to the balcony and, walking to the balustrade, rested
her hand upon the broad parapet, looking down into the street, which
seemed a terribly long way below. And even as she did so, she felt the
balcony sag slowly beneath her.

She turned in a fright and leapt towards the window; but at that minute
there was a loud crack, and the stone floor dropped suddenly beneath
her.

That's part of your crazy ideas,
What is supposed to be my delusion?
You mean I am under the impression that I am somebody important?
Yes--you think you're the Countess of Moron!

31.title: _The Strange Countess_             _Chapter Thirty-One_
31.body: You've had an uncomfortable day, but you've got your friend to blame,
Why did you tell Mrs. Rooks that I was mad?
Why do you say that I think I'm the Countess of Moron?
There's a nice little place down there,
Are you going to put me there?
You? My dear, you're the last person in the world I should put there.
Do you ever speak the truth?

32.title: _The Strange Countess_             _Chapter Thirty-Two_
32.body: That is the why of Gallows Farm,
From to-day I am on my own; I can't start too soon,
No. He was driving; but he was grinning like an ape. That shows!
said his lordship, with perfect truth.
Not a very cheerful looking place, is it?
It is too late to talk about mistakes,
There's a woman in the car,

33.title: _The Strange Countess_            _Chapter Thirty-Three_
33.body: You were lucky to find me in,
Is there any likelihood of Dorn coming back?
He's back! In fact, he is practically under this roof!
What the devil do you mean?
It was a question of foresight, and I saw farthest,
Has he recovered from the drug?
I may want the other woman--later,
I had better bring Reddle down,
What will you do with him?
I don't know--it seems pretty awful,
What will happen if he gets after me?
Good evening, Miss Reddle. Won't you sit down?
I'm afraid you've had a very unhappy experience,
I don't quite understand you, Mr. Praye.
You mean the Countess of Moron?
Am I here by her orders?
You will know one of these days,
She's here for the same reason that you are here,
The first is that you marry me!

34.title: _The Strange Countess_            _Chapter Thirty-Four_
34.body: Your mother is in this house.
And have you come to take me away?
Reddle? Then Mrs. Reddle gave you her name?
But you told your mother you would!
I'll give you as much time as it will take you to sign this paper.
I can do nothing until I have seen Mr. Dorn.
He came here this morning, looking for you, and----
I don't want you, Tappatt. Shut the door, damn you!
Go into the back, quick! The dogs won't hurt you,
Where will he have taken her? What will happen?
Nothing; they will not dare injure her.
It will burn like tinder. I'm sorry.
But they told me you were dead?
I'll tell you about it some day,
There is enough to get us to the nearest village,
Yes, I passed a big car, with three or four people in it.
Then we also will take the Newbury Road,
But how did you get out?
I know one person who will be happy to-night,
I wonder whether she got the day off?
Mr. Dorn, do you really think that there's no danger to my mother?
Have you Miss Smith with you?
She went to Gallows Farm with his lordship.
I saw no sign of a car, hired or otherwise,
No, no, not that terrible woman.
So you know--or rather, you guess?
I'm going to tell you something,
Why, of course, you've worked very hard for me.
And I have been paid very well,
I'm not an authority on these matters,

35.title: _The Strange Countess_            _Chapter Thirty-Five_
35.body: What about that car of ours? We hired it by the hour,
That is the gallery of the music-room!
So you have seen your daughter, Mrs. Pinder?
Yes, madam, I have seen Lois.
A dear, sweet girl! I am very proud, whatever happens to me.
What do you think will happen to you?
I don't know, but I am prepared for anything now.
You know a great deal too much for my comfort, madam,
and much too much for the safety of my friends.
You fool, you madman, what are you doing?
He pointed an accusing finger at his mother.
I can say it was an accident.
Is there any trouble, my lady?
I think you would be well advised to ask my son to change his plans,

36.title: _The Strange Countess_            _Chapter Thirty-Six_
36.body: Tell Henry that I wish the Rolls to be at the door in ten minutes,
There's somebody at the door, miss: will you open it for me?
You can't come in here, ma'am,
I wish to see Miss Reddle,
So it was you? I might have guessed that.
I should have opposed it more if I had known what I know now,
Well, I suppose everybody knows now?
The late Earl of Moron married twice,
And now I have something else to say.
I'd have recognised you if I hadn't heard your fine, deep voice,
Don't be silly, Selwyn. Of course it makes all the difference!
That's the queerest aspect of the whole case.
I shall when your ladyship has said 'thank you.'
